summary: A glimpse into the playful and confident world of Aretha Franklin, showcasing her charisma, humor, and dynamic personality through various interview highlights.

events_list.video_caption: The video features an interview with Aretha Franklin, conducted by an interviewer who asks if she is broke. Aretha responds confidently, stating she has no money problems. The interviewer then asks if she is broke, to which Aretha replies, "No money problems, whatsoever." The interviewer continues by asking if she is a diva, and Aretha humorously responds, "That's...Toni Braxton...That's not me." The video then transitions to a title card that reads "The Queen of Shade and Laughs (BEST INTERVIEW MOMENTS)." The setting appears to be a dimly lit room with a dark background, and Aretha is wearing a patterned outfit. The video captures a light-hearted and humorous exchange between the interviewer and Aretha, showcasing her wit and confidence.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a conversation between two speakers: A male speaker questions a female speaker "are you broke?". The female speaker denies this, stating she has "no money problems". The male speaker rephrases the question, and she reiterates "no money problems whatsoever". She then references "Toni Braxton" and states "that's not me". This conversational segment is suddenly interrupted by loud, rhythmic music that sounds like trap. The music is intense and overwhelming, potentially used for dramatic effect.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a woman in a cream-colored suit seated at a piano, engaged in a conversation with a man in a light gray suit. The man gestures animatedly while speaking, and the woman listens attentively. The background features a large window with a view of a garden and a vase of white flowers on the piano. The text overlay reads, "Interviewer: it has such a range that no matter the key, the lows are too low... and the highs are too high." The scene transitions to a close-up of the woman, who responds with, "You can go from one end of the spectrum to the other." The video then shifts to a different setting, showing the woman in a white outfit with curly hair, sitting in a chair with a Christmas tree and poinsettias in the background. The next scene features the woman in a white outfit with a green necklace, seated on a white couch in a studio setting with a Christmas tree and poinsettias in the background. The text overlay reads, "The Meredith Vieira Show." The woman is engaged in a conversation with another woman in a black top and red pants, seated across from her on a white couch. The background features a large screen with the text "meredith THE MEREDITH VIEIRA SHOW" and poinsettias. The video then transitions to a close-up of the woman in a yellow outfit, standing in front of a neon sign that reads "Aretha." The woman is wearing large earrings and appears to be speaking. The video concludes with the woman in the yellow outfit continuing to speak in front of the neon sign, with the background remaining consistent throughout the scene.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip opens with two speakers, likely male, discussing a range that makes the highs too high and the lows too low, with one person sounding skeptical. A female voice interjects, disagreeing about range. The first female voice then speaks again, asking about Beyonce, and mentioning they are a fan of Beyonce, followed by a confirming statement that Beyonce is also a fan. A male voice then interjects saying, "yes." Finally, a female voice says that if they really, really had to, they would, but since they really, really don't have to, they don't.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a woman with short, dark hair, wearing a blue top, set against a blurred background. The scene transitions to another woman with short, dark hair, dressed in a yellow top, with a green, leafy background. The next scene features a woman with long, blonde hair, wearing a yellow top, seated in a room with a white wall and a black couch. The text overlay reads "SHOWBIZ ON LOCATION @L.A.'S NOKIA THEATRE" and "ARETHA FRANKLIN ON MARIAH CAREY AS NEW 'IDOL' JUDGE: 'I'M HAPPY FOR HER'." The video then shows a woman with long, blonde hair, wearing a white blazer, seated on a couch in a room with a desk, chair, and mirror in the background. The text overlay remains the same. The scene shifts to a close-up of the woman in the yellow top, with the text overlay changing to "MARIAH CAREY REPORTEDLY TO BE PAID $18 MILLION TO JUDGE 'IDOL' CONTESTANTS." The video then transitions to a woman with short, dark hair, wearing a white sweatshirt with "ARETHA" written on it, holding a drink and standing in a backstage area with ladders and equipment visible. The text overlay reads "Aretha: Leave these old dudes alone, the younger brothers are turning it out!" The video concludes with a close-up of the woman in the white sweatshirt, with the same text overlay.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a conversational tone. One male speaker proposes discussing sex, promising an intelligent take. A second, possibly female, speaker agrees, with the first speaker describing it as "fine and very sexy". Laughter is heard. An exchange follows where it is mentioned a source confirmed something, possibly from inside sources. A child interjects with singing. A shift happens, and the sounds become unintelligible.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a woman in a white shirt with "Michigan" written on it, standing in a busy backstage area, surrounded by people and equipment. She is speaking, and the text on the screen reads, "Aretha: Leave these old dudes alone, the younger brothers are turning it out!" (Aretha: Dejen a estos viejos tranquilos, los hermanos más jóvenes están haciendo un gran trabajo!). The scene transitions to a close-up of another woman with short curly hair, wearing a black outfit, sitting in front of a vase of yellow flowers. She appears to be speaking, and the background is softly blurred, focusing on her expression. The video then shows a woman in a white outfit with a yellow background, speaking with a hand gesture, and the text reads, "Aretha: No, no, no, no darling, I'm just a baby." (Aretha: No, no, no, no querida, solo soy una niña). The scene shifts to a woman in a black leather jacket, sitting in front of a window with a blurred green background, speaking with a serious expression. The video continues with a woman in a black outfit with a blurred outdoor background, speaking with a neutral expression. The final scene features a woman with blonde hair, wearing a black blazer and white shirt, sitting in a well-decorated room with plants and furniture, speaking with a confident expression. The text on the screen reads, "Aretha: Oh, I'm gonna be the foxiest grandma that you ever saw!" (Aretha: Oh, voy a ser la abuela más astuta que hayas visto!). The video captures various women in different settings, each engaged in conversation, with text providing context to their dialogue.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a child exclaiming excitedly, "Turn it out!" This is followed by a woman's voice, initially light-hearted and humorous, speculating about dating younger men, saying they should have been "just a little older, like maybe 10, 15 years older." Her tone shifts to teasing self-deprecation as she insists she's "just a baby," countering someone claiming this is not true, and she goes on to say, "Lies, lies and more lies!" She then shifts back to humorous confidence, declaring that she will be "the foxiest grandmother." Throughout the clip, there is consistent background noise of what sounds like running water.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a series of interviews with various women, each dressed in different outfits and seated in various settings. The first woman, with curly hair, is seen in a brown outfit, while the second woman, with short hair, wears a black outfit with a leopard print collar. The third woman, with short hair, is dressed in a white outfit, and the fourth woman, with short hair, wears a black outfit with a floral pattern. The fifth woman, with long hair, is dressed in a white outfit with a striped collar. Throughout the video, the women are engaged in conversations, with some gesturing with their hands. The background settings vary, with some women seated in front of floral arrangements and others in front of a lamp. The video includes text overlays, such as "BMA Black Music Archive," indicating the source of the footage. The women appear to be discussing their experiences and opinions, with one woman expressing her positive reaction to wearing a tutu. The video captures a range of emotions and expressions, providing insight into the women's personalities and perspectives.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a female speaking assertively, cautioning someone not to say anything about her gown.  A male voice then enters, initially conversational as he asks about the speaker's appearance in a tutu, but then switches to a complimentary tone. Another female voice interjects, followed by upbeat music with vocals. A male voice announces that a door is open, and another male voice expresses a reaction, possibly surprise. A female speaker asks a rhetorical question about gullibility, and a male voice responds they may be with the right person. The first female voice returns, clarifying that she will not be stupid. A male voice follows, mentioning a reef waiting to be born. An exclamation interrupts this. Background sounds are audible throughout, potentially suggesting an environment with movement or activity.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man in a suit and glasses, speaking in an indoor setting with a blurred background, suggesting a formal or professional environment. The scene transitions to a woman in a black leather jacket, seated indoors with a window showing greenery in the background, indicating a relaxed or casual setting. She appears to be engaged in a conversation, gesturing with her hand. The next scene features another woman with long black hair, wearing a light pink top, seated in a room with a vase of white flowers and a lamp in the background, suggesting a cozy and intimate atmosphere. The video then shifts to a woman with curly hair, wearing a patterned top, seated in a room with a couch and a neutral-colored wall, indicating a comfortable and homely environment. Throughout the video, the 'Black Music Archive' logo is visible in the top left corner, indicating the source or context of the footage. The video captures a series of individuals in different settings, each engaged in conversation or contemplation, creating a diverse and dynamic narrative.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a male speaker prompting another person for reactions to different singers. The second speaker, seemingly female, is hesitant to comment on Nicki Minaj, stating, "I'm going to pass on that one," followed by an enigmatic statement about not sharing details. The overall tone is lighthearted. Ambient sounds suggest an outdoor environment, possibly a park, with chirping birds providing a gentle background ambiance.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a woman in a vibrant pink outfit passionately singing into a microphone, surrounded by a band playing instruments in a studio setting. The scene transitions to a close-up of another woman in a black headscarf, speaking in an interview setting, with the text "Interviewer: Could you recall what it felt like listening to your father's sermons?" displayed at the bottom. The narrative then shifts to a woman in a white outfit holding a trophy, standing in front of a backdrop with the Grammy logo, with the text "In 67, young and sassy" appearing at the bottom. The video continues with various scenes of women in different settings, including a woman in a gray sweater dancing in a room with people in the background, and another woman with a flower in her hair, wearing a white top, in an outdoor setting. The video concludes with a woman in a blue dress, adorned with red earrings, speaking in an indoor setting, with the "BMA Black Music Archive" logo visible in the top left corner throughout the video. The video captures a range of emotions and settings, from musical performances to personal interviews and celebratory moments, highlighting the diverse experiences and achievements of the women featured.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with two female speakers in an outdoor setting with ambient street noise. One asks "Are you shooting that right now?" The other responds, "Yeah wait, what kind of moment is this? Television shooting television, right?" The speech cuts to a male voice asking about remembering feelings related to a father's sermons. This is followed by a woman stating that she doesn't "want to start off on that note." There is a transition to speech with indiscernible gender, saying it has been a "whirlwind of a week." Another male speaker says something and then someone says, "roll the arms", and there is some indistinct speech in the background. A woman talks about 1967, being young and sassy, and 1994, sassy and classy. The audio transitions to "Oh yeah, I can hang" then "I'm home girl." There is a comment about eating a lemon ball. The audio goes back to the earlier male voice speaking about "sex," then "lust," and then a woman tells him he has her mixed up with someone else. The clip ends with a male voice asking who gives you goosebumps.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a series of interviews with Aretha Franklin, captured in a cozy indoor setting. In the first scene, Aretha, dressed in a black outfit and cap, is seated on a couch, animatedly gesturing while speaking to an interviewer in a suit. The text overlay reads, "Aretha: My man did last night!" indicating a lively conversation. The scene transitions to another interview where Aretha, now in a yellow jacket, is seated in front of a vibrant floral backdrop. The interviewer, wearing a red jacket, asks a question, and the text overlay reads, "Interviewer: R-E-S-P-E-C-T take out P-C-E." Aretha responds with, "Take care of T-C-B," followed by, "Take care of business," as she continues to speak. The interviewer then questions, "She transcribed it wrong?" and clarifies, "We thought it meant take out P-C-E to get rest." The video captures Aretha's expressive demeanor and the engaging nature of the interviews, set against a warm and inviting environment.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a sound that resembles an animal howl, possibly a dog or wolf. Then a female speaker talks with a somewhat sarcastic tone, first about "respect," "take out PCE," calling it the "worst rendition ever." She then mentions "TCB." Another female speaker joins, clarifying the phrase means "take care of business." The first speaker suspects that the original phrase was transcribed wrong, and the audio ends with a dramatic exclamation.

events_list.video_caption: The video opens with a woman in a yellow jacket adorned with a pink flower, seated in a room filled with greenery and flowers, engaging in a conversation. The scene transitions to a man in a suit and tie standing among an audience, with the text "Aretha: No. No." displayed at the bottom, indicating a dialogue. The narrative continues with a woman with curly hair, speaking against a backdrop of flowers, with the text "We almost went toe to toe there for a moment." suggesting a tense or intense conversation. The video then shifts to a woman with red hair, wearing a brown jacket, speaking against a dark background, followed by a woman with blonde hair in a black outfit, speaking in front of a wall with a heart-shaped design. The scene transitions to a woman in a white shirt and black vest, speaking in a room with greenery, with the text "I hear myself, I know when someone has been influenced by me." displayed at the bottom, indicating a reflective moment. The video then shows a woman with curly hair in a white outfit, speaking in an outdoor setting, with the text "Interviewer: Who do you admire?" displayed at the bottom, indicating an interview. The final scene features a woman in a white outfit performing on stage, with the audience visible in the background, creating a lively atmosphere. The video concludes with a black screen displaying the text "BMA BLACK MUSIC ARCHIVE" in white, indicating the source of the footage.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a person exclaiming "Oh, I'm sorry." Another person, possibly male, says they were "taking care of business." A female voice replies, "Well, that's entirely different. I'm glad I straightened it out. I'm glad you did." The male voice then asks, "Aretha, among the singers today, who do you see as being the next queen of soul?" Followed by background noises. Then a female voice says: "We almost went toe-to-toe there for a moment. And we both sashayed away from each other, giving each other the finger." She adds that if she were the age of the little girls, she might have been squealing and screaming herself. The female voice then requests to "turn that down for the moment." A male voice says, "Guys, control room, let's turn it down. Come on, this is speaking." A female voice then says that "Some of the rap is good, some of it is not good, and some of it is wretched." Then says, "It's wonderful, when one is influencing to the degree that I was." She says, "I hear myself, I know when someone is being influenced." The male voice then says, "Everyone talks about 'Oh, I love Aretha, I model myself after Aretha.'" Then asks the female voice, "Who's your favorite? Who is the person you admire? Is there anyone you admire?" The female voice ponders, then says, "After myself." She laughs and says "Listen, my dear, my darling, my sweet wonderful one, if these people don't hear this tonight, you won't be getting paid. Did you hear that?"

events_list.video_caption: The video features a woman with short hair, wearing a black leather jacket, seated in a dimly lit room. The logo "BMA Black Music Archive" is visible in the top left corner of the screen. The woman appears to be engaged in a conversation, as her facial expressions change throughout the video. The background is dark, with a hint of a patterned fabric visible behind her. The lighting focuses on her face, highlighting her features and expressions. The video transitions to a different scene where the woman is now outdoors, with a blurred green background suggesting foliage. She is wearing a different outfit, possibly a black top with a patterned collar, and her hair is styled differently. The lighting is brighter, and the atmosphere is more natural. The woman continues to speak, with her facial expressions conveying emotion and engagement. The video captures the woman's expressions and movements, providing a glimpse into her personality and the context of her conversation.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a female speaker recounting a story about Lauryn Hill, who said that after the speaker's vocal session, the booth "smelled like church," pure and full of energy. The speaker asks what church smells like, then answers that it smells like old books to her. Another male speaker is heard, and the first speaker mentions he is hot and there are plans for another dinner. The scene is punctuated by music in a talk show style.

events_list.video_caption: The video opens with a woman in a white dress singing on stage, accompanied by a choir and a band, with the text "BMA BLACK MUSIC ARCHIVE" visible in the top left corner. The scene transitions to a woman in a black leather jacket speaking, with the text "I saw some pictures, not very attractive or flattering." displayed at the bottom. The video then shows a group of women on a talk show set, with the text "Aretha: I'm STILL skinny." appearing at the bottom. The next scene features a woman in a blue sweater dancing in a kitchen, followed by a woman in a black leather jacket speaking again, with the text "Aretha: Patti, you know you 54." displayed at the bottom. The video then shows a woman in a black leather jacket speaking in a different setting, followed by a woman in a white shirt speaking in a studio, with the text "I gained a few pounds..." displayed at the bottom. The final scene shows a woman in a white shirt sitting in a recording studio, with the text "...and gained 50 pounds in the interim." displayed at the bottom. Throughout the video, the "BMA BLACK MUSIC ARCHIVE" text remains visible in the top left corner, and the scenes transition between different settings, including a stage, a talk show set, a kitchen, and a recording studio. The video captures various women speaking and performing, with a focus on their expressions and gestures, as well as the different environments they are in.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with male speech in a casual, interview-like tone, discussing Whitney's mother as one of three backup singers. A female speaker interrupts in a louder tone, seemingly amused and sarcastic, expressing disbelief, and then makes a joke. Her tone is playful. An upbeat music track begins, fading into the background. The female speaker then matter-of-factly states she loves to eat. Following this, a new female voice is heard, initially assertive, and then switches to lighthearted and conversational. Lastly, a final female voice, in a more poised and measured tone, expresses liking a gown's design while admitting to having gained a few pounds due to quitting smoking.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a conversation between two individuals seated in a room with patterned wallpaper and striped chairs. The first person, a man with a mustache, is dressed in a suit and tie, gesturing with his hands as he speaks. The second person, a woman with short curly hair, is wearing a red outfit and pearl jewelry, listening attentively. The scene transitions to a close-up of the woman, who appears to be speaking, with a chandelier visible in the background. The video then shifts to a different setting, showing a close-up of another woman with short hair, wearing a white shirt and a dark vest, against a plain background. Throughout the video, the text "BMA" and "Black Music Archive" is visible, indicating the source of the footage. The atmosphere is formal and conversational, with the individuals engaged in a serious discussion.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a question posed by a male speaker asking, "How do you want to be remembered?" A female speaker responds in a conversational tone, stating, "In a number of ways," and then says, "The lady takes care of business." This is followed by a change in the soundscape to include loud, intense hip hop music, with a very aggressive rhythm that appears to be a shift in scene.
